monogr.title: The Furies· : With vertues encomium. Or The image of honour. In two bookes of epigrammes, satyricall and encomiasticke. By R.N
monogr.author: Niccols, Richard

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
MAny idle humorists, whose singularity allowes nothing good, that is common, in this frantik age, esteeme of verses vpon which the vulgar in a Stationers Shop, hath once breathed as of a peece of infection, in whose fine fingers no papers are holesome, but such, as passe by priuate manuscription; Others because to many impudent Poetasters, that can scarce read a Verse, doe daily pester the Printers Presse with their paltries, will without trial, eyther for dislike of the title, distast of the Authors name, or some such idle scruple, censure anie mans endeuours with: Qui nescit, versus tamen audet fingere; For the first of these, I leaue them to the curious conceits of the close Cabinet: the last I would haue to know, that Hic nihil inuitâ dicam, faciamue Mineruâ. To him, who out of a seeming seueritie, distastes all thinges, that sauour not of grauite, and sayes Epigrammes are toyes vnworthie eyther his expence of time or suspence of opinion. I answer, & in ipso ioco, aliquid probi ingenij lumen eluceat; Yet I confesse, these to bee Epigrams and but slight; in placing of which, for that I obserue no method or order, if his austeritie, out of ignorance, doe cauill with me, I referre him to the Prince of all writers in this kind Val. Martialis. I desire the impartial Reader, to know, that for the follies of such and the like, I
heere inuocate the Furies, who in the first part of this Pamphlet, alternatly succeed in the scourg of vanitie; to the last part I referre you in his proper place, wishing all vertu • us Gentlewomen, eyther to passe ouer my Furies, as impertinent to their sex or mildly to ce • sure, or at le • st not misco • strue my intent: if question be made, why I make three parts of the first part, and but one of the last; • ecause the best of vs hath three partes of vice, for one of v • rtue, bre • fly I craue▪ but that the simplicitie of my intent may be free from the malignitie of interpretation, in all other thinges I submit my selfe to censure.
